reviews.name: dnik
reviews.title_review: HD AMOLED is a major deal braker
reviews.body: I picked it up from major electronics chain, an impulse decision but I didn't have any doubts concidering how much praises I read abot this phone. Basically on paper it seemed to have everything that main competitor was missing, a great big screen, robust and responsive performance, and previously only having used Gingerbread devices, the ICS and upcoming Jelly Bean update were obviously a gigantic leap for Android. Imidiately taking advantage of Google Play market, I started loading it with apps, and coming from the "evil" side I was surprised that you can actually get malware on Android, but than I started receiving annoying ads in notification bar. I tried all major anti virus apps, and the 5th or 6th Malware detector, was finally able to detect the pesky source of ads. Returning to actual phone usage, battery life was never a concern, as I was planning of getting additional batteries, overall it has outstanding battery life and with a few tweaks no additional batteries are even needed as it makes through 9-5 like any other phone. Coming from iphone 3gs, camera alone seemed like a killer feature. I have a descent Nikon DSLR, but the photos looked stunning, not really pro grade of course, but with some basic editing more than sufficient for cool daily shots. The screen I figured would resolve the size constraint of a 3.5 inch I had before, and just seemed more natural and even enough to replace a tablet, escpecially with capability of loading entire movie collection 64gb card and take it on a long trip or etc, to preserve the valuable gigabytes that come with a data plan. The downside the screen itself looked unnatural, striking reds, that I had to hide the red Contacts icon. The buttom line, to decrease the battery consumption, Samsung had to compromise the screen quality, dimming down the screen, and boosting color temperature. The result, the whites are not as white as lcd, colors looks oversaturated, but blacks are very dark, so videos look great, but some apps especially using same apps on ipad, appear to have weird tones to them. For the web surfing and reading text I would prefer colder tones. To make things even worse, I started to experience eye strain after 10-15 minutes of usage. It went away, after continual usage, so I could use it for 3 hours and be ok, but only feeling the pressure in my eyes after using this phone. I though it was all part of adaptation process to HD Amoled, but it was getting worse and even persisted when I wasn't looking directly at the screen, as I was driving and using it as Gps. Still once it was off, I imidiately felt a relief in my eyes. I was trying to replicate this uncomfortable sensation in my eyes by staring at other screens at full brightness, but no discomfort whatsoever, Googling for this confirmed my suspicion that it was something wrong with the screen, as other users had similar symptoms when using S3. I also stumbled upon one youtube video compating iphone and s3. The video was taken in low light settings, and S3 screen was flickering, while iPhone was static. Its was like almost like reliving the 90s, where flickering screens were all so common with crt monitors and tvs. That is also time when we installed protective screens on monitors, to decrease the tiny amounts of radiation emmited by screens. So to prove my theory I returned the phone and got another one, and the eye strain was practically gone the next day. to sum it up, I don't care how many more patents Samsung needs to infringe, but I am not buying another Samsung or HD Amoled phone untill they come up with better screens. Please do your homework before buying, and obviously in its ambition to beat Apple in numbers, Samsung has chosen to use inferior screen technology called Pentile. Please don't gamble with your eye sight by trying to save a few dollars, and obviously now with recent price reduction this phone has entered a bargain phone segment.

reviews.name: austin_bird
reviews.title_review: Phone is okay, be careful when buying from Amazon Wireless
reviews.body: Phone problems: 1. Phone sometimes get too hot 2. Battery charge comes for only 1 day with very light activity 3. If I get international missed calls and I call back using the same missed call log, it doesn't work. I have to search in the contact and make a call. Some angels complained about me posting my bad experience here, looks like first amendment has been buried. Amazon ordering application has a bug: I had a very bad experience with my Amazon wireless purchase. Here is sequence of events. 1. 11/23/2012 I bought two "Samsung Galaxy 3" with 2 years contract with Sprint. 2. I wanted my old number ported for one phone and a new phone number for another one. 3. I got two phones, new phone number and activation instructions on 11/28 4. I decided to return phones and not activate sprint contract because of CDMA phones 5. I returned phones on 12/01 and did not activate my account with sprint 6. Amazon still went ahead and asked Sprint to port my old number (from T-mobile) 7. I lost my T-mobile service 12/8. This is when problems started for me. When I asked T-mobile to re-activate my service, they said it would be a new 24 month contract, which I didn't want to do. 8. I had to buy another phone, so I decided to buy same two (Samsung Galaxy 3) with two years contract with AT&T. I ordered on 12/8, but the web application didn't allow me to keep my old number. When I talked to Amazon customer service, I was told during activation time I can ask AT&T if they can port my old number from sprint. 9. On 12/12 AT&T agreed to port my number from Sprint and discarded new phone numbers given by Amazon. It took 90 minutes on the phone call with AT&T and Sprint guys to resolve all issues. 10. On 12/19 I get a mail from stupid Amazon that My AT&T service has been disconnected and my credit card will be charged $500.00 (discount given to phones for 2 yrs contract). 11. on 12/21 I called Amazon, AT&T to resolve the issue, not charge $500.00..I am not still optimistic about this. Be careful when buying from Amazon..

Also the build quality feels a bit flimsy and cheap due to its plastic body. When comparing build quality to an iphone or htc one series this phone just feels flat out cheap. And last but not least, i think the screen is great but it depends on personal preference, the gsIII super amoled gives nice rich colors, but can be a little over exaggerated, as where the iphone and one x will give you more natural colors( pixel density is basically the same on all these phones so not really a factor, except gsIII share sub pixels, where the iphone and htc dont share but its still a tie in my opinion).

title_item: Nokia Lumia 1520, Black 16GB (AT&T)
description: Nokia Lumia 1520 16GB Unlocked GSM Yellow Windows Phone
about: Display: 6.0-inches
Camera: 20-MP
Processor Speed: 2.2 GHz

reviews.name: Pamela Castillo
reviews.title_review: So far, I love this phablet. (phone and tablet)
reviews.body: Jan-2 2019 This is an upgrade from my 5 year old, Nokia Lumina 520, Windows 8.1 phone cannot be upgraded to the Windows 10 operating system. The much newer Nokia Lumia 1520 also, has the Windows 8.1 operating system but it is on the list of Lumina phones that canbe upgraded to the Windows 10 operating system. Which I did with did without any problems. The 6" screen quality is gorgeous. Takes beautiful pictures, no issues getting online. Sound is much better than my old 520. The 1520 with the Win10 OS, supports Dolby with 5.1 headphones has an equalizer. The dial pad is easy to use as it has a much bigger. There a a ton of available apps. Some are truly free others you have to shell out some money. So far, I have not any issues switching between apps. The 1520 meets all of my needs. Why didn't I buy this device before? As with all of my reviews I will update this one in about 6 months, or earlier if problems occur.

reviews.name: Vandy-SJ
reviews.title_review: Almost a replacement for a laptop
reviews.body: Upgrading from my older, very reliable and functional Nokia 900 Windows Phone to my new Nokia 1520 Windows Phone is all good! The six-inch screen is much sharper with better resolution, and provides easier to read text and webpages on the larger screen. The faster processor (quad-core) and more memory provides much better performance for all functions and features. The 1520 is about the size as a desktop phone handset to hold and use for phone calls, so for me the larger size phone is not a problem and audio call quality is excellent. I chose a horizontal belt-loop carry case to carry it around, and that works for me. Battery capacity is good for my typical all-day use, and data-intensive activities seem to be the biggest battery drain. After an overnight recharge, its ready for another business day. I'm still discovering the newest features and functions. So far, the Cortana voice-assist has worked very well, and voice recognition (of my voice) and the Cortana answers have been spot-on and quick. I do most of my business work on a laptop, but this 1520 is serving as an excellent device for a mobile extension to my office. I haven't tried Skype yet, but the Lumia Cameras (both selfie and front-facing) are excellent and produce very high quality images (20 MP front-facing). Since the phone purchase, I received and applied one Windows 8.1 Update via AT&T (downloaded using WiFi connection) that was uneventful, auto-restarted three times (included both firmware and OS upgrades) during the upgrade process, and resulted in better performance on all levels. Almost a replacement for a laptop - getting closer anyway.

reviews.name: kennelhater
reviews.body: I am a huge apple fan, I have had every iPhone up until the iphone4 and was in the market for an upgrade A few reasons i picked this over latest iPhone 1) the iPhone is too darn small, sorry it's really a good thing to carry but when you use it for web browsing and lots of email it gets hard to read as i get older 2) the iPhone is more money 3) i'm bored with IOS, i get that if it isn't broke don't fix it but cmon apple !! and when are you gonna have unified ui across all platforms Ok, so now about this phone, it's HUGE !!! don't complain about it folks the measurements are in product description The build quality is very nice , screen is high enough resolution for pictures and videos to look nice and glare isn't too bad I like having removable storage (microsd) and standard microusb plugs for charging The button layout is a bit of an issue, you have to watch where you grab the phone or else you adjust power/volume , etc The camera is where this phone shines, the pictures are beautiful , I am very pleased with it I haven't installed many apps yet, heck office works natively and i like being able to customize all the tiles where I want them Bottom line is it's worth $100 all day long and I'm glad to upgrade

reviews.name: Duncan C. St Ives
reviews.body: My 5th Windows phone since switching from iPhone 4s. Software as usual was excellent... Very stable and reliable with all the normal functions I use every day working flawlessly, intuitively and quickly. Biggest use of my phone is at work where I rely on Onenote, Word, Excel, Xbox Music and Audible to get me through my day. On the hardware side Nokia gets it right again... With a high end processor the speed never fails to impress the screen is a joy to look at and the super sensitive touch works perfectly while riding my dirt bikes with gloves. Additionally the phone is pretty thin, takes abuse (though I have a case) and has second to none battery life (Literally: http://wmpoweruser.com/nokia-lumia-1520-demonstrates-amazing-battery-life-in-gsmarena-test/). Only downside I can think of is occasional mis-calibration of the display brightness when set to auto (comes up way too dim) but always corrects its self within 10 seconds and occurs pretty infrequently when you unlock the phone... Basically a non issue. As far as apps go I have everything I want though I am not a huge mobile gamer so I can comment on that but my phone currently has 325 apps on it about 80-100 of which get used once a week or more and includes all the big name apps (most of which were missing when I first got my phone. As few frequently used common sample: Facebook Facebook page manager (full feature client for managing pages like businesses, events and causes) Chase bank Etrade financial Youtube (though I normally use one of the many excellent third party clients since the 1st party app isn't as good) Unit converter Flashlight Amazon Audible Netflix WPtorrentpro (bit torrent client) Dominoes Pizza Maaloo Outdoors (a outdoor mapping and tracking client that allows saving of track including import and export with dropbox and skydrive support... Great for ATV/Dirt biking, hiking, etc)

reviews.name: Danger Mouse
reviews.body: Nokia has been building great phones for an eternity and this device continues Nokia's leadership in excellent quality devices. I've had the 920 and the 925 recently, and I was expecting this phone to be at least on par with the other two but I was not expecting it to be leaps and bounds ahead. It exactly that however. Visually, the device is similar to the 920 in design. Larger, thinner, and far more powerful. For those who are appcentric, make certain that apps you use everyday are on this platform before you switch. Once you've decided that excellent telephony trumps apps, it's a no brainer. The 1520 brings top of the line specs to the table whether you're looking for resolution, screen size, expandability, performance, or longevity. It's all here. My average battery life is 32 hours. the downside is the dialer, it's massive and often requires two hands to dial. The work around is to use live tiles, or to use bluetooth or voice control dialing which is superb.

reviews.name: Thomas
reviews.title_review: The phone works great, Windows 10 Mobile, needs work.
reviews.body: The only reason I say that is because I have had every kind of mobile operating system worth its salt: IOS, Android, and Windows. Back when I had the lumia 920 it was great, I loved the operating system, but since then Microsoft has abandoned the windows phone, that's too bad as some people swore by them, including me. I broke my android and wanted to go back to window phone, I was a little disappointed that not only had the apps avoided windows phone as they had before, but microsoft themselves have as well. I would like to see a monster update for these devices, to try and revive the market. The phone worked well, screen was responsive, camera is the best by a longshot if you ask me, and the phone is dirt cheap compared to other devices. If you aren't in it for the apps, definitely pick it up.

reviews.name: anon
reviews.title_review: Microsoft Phone 8 is an improvement over my old iPhone 4
reviews.body: The form factor has distinct benefits and drawback. The square corners,larger size, and extra weight compared to my old iPhone requires some adjustment. It fits fine in a jacket pocket but not so much in a pants pocket. The larger display is great and the battery lasts for several days. The Windows 8 display and navigation takes awhile to get used to. I have Windows 8 on my touch-screen PC and almost never use it as the Windows 7 format works fine. Now that I appreciate the advances in Windows Phone 8, maybe I'll use Windows 8 (PC version) more. Setting up the synchronizing of email was easy, but syncing the calendar and contacts took quite an effort. The Microsoft, AT&T, and Nokia web sites have instructions for syncing, but it is not clear which software and platforms are used in each process. My Windows 8 PC runs both Outlook mail and Windows mail. Google hosts my mail. AT&T provides the communications service. Nokia also has some server processes. I ended up with multiple email accounts, contact lists, and calendars on my PC before getting the right combination on the phone. Downloading apps is easy and fast from the MIcrosoft Store. Initially I was concerned that a couple of my old favorites were not programmed for Windows Phone, but most others are now available. The apps start up and run fast, and the display makes them easier to use.

reviews.name: TexasTea
reviews.body: I purchased this phone from a third party Amazon retailer as used. The retailer was honest about the phone and described what was good about it and what was not so good about it. I purchased a replacement rear camera lens that was previously broken and identified by the seller. The phone worked flawlessly. I was able to upgrade the phone to a newer version of Windows Phone and am very happy with it. I have owned this Nokia Lumina 1520 for several months now and like everything about it that it is NOT. Mainly it is NOT an Apple iPhone which is what this Nokia Replaced, and yes, I just slid my AT&T sim card out of my iPhone and into the Nokia. Works perfectly and was able to move my contacts easily from my old phone to this one. The Nokia 1520 is a big phone, more like a phablet than a phone. This smartphone is not for everyone's taste as it is large, somewhat cumbersome, but takes awesome pictures and video. I feel more comfortable with the Windows interface rather than Apple. Apple makes a great phone but I really got tired of the hype and how much I needed the bleeding edge of their technology, so I got off the train and went to Nokia. Now that Nokia has sold their phone business to Microsoft, I may have a different opinion with the next generation of Surface Phone or whatever they are going to call it. I may keep what I have for a few more years and not upgrade at all, I am that happy with it now.

reviews.name: C. S.
reviews.body: This is a BIG phone, so it may not be for everyone, but I like it a lot. Screen is big and bright and responsive. No glitchy issues, at all. I like the Windows live tile design, and once you get familiar with how to get around in the OS, it's as good as anything else out there. Camera takes sharp, color-correct pictures. Low-light is good. Close-ups are very good. The cool thing is the very tight integration with the Windows operating system which makes sharing, viewing and editing files between computer and phone very easy. The app store does not have as wide a selection as Apple or Android, but most of the popular ones are there, and there is almost always an app that will do the job. Battery life is good. I can usually go about a day and a half before it needs a charge, but I'll typically charge it at night, so it's very rare that I run out of power. The speakers are pretty powerful on this phone, so you can really crank up the music if you want.

reviews.name: Didier Billiouxe
reviews.body: This is my 4th one of these. I had switched to the Lumia 950 after I broke the third one. When I activated this one and tried to use it, it became excruciating painful to use as anything other than a basic phone. Calls, messaging, and a bit of Cortana was it. Microsoft has abandoned the Windows Phone OS, and the Edge Browser. Some of the other Microsoft software that used to work seamlessly with this phone crashed constantly, and no developers are working on this platform.

reviews.name: vette328
reviews.title_review: Windows cell phone are not manufactured anymore.
reviews.body: This Nokia Lumia 1520, Black 16GB AT&T has issues with the Sims card portal and cannot be used. I have alerted the Seller about the cellphone and has been reassured that my account will be credited back the amount spent on the cellphone. I will just have to cut my loses because I ordered a case to fit that cellphone. There is no one in this area that works on Windows cellphones and it would have required me to spend so much more to correct the problem. In any case, it is my current cellphone just a smaller version.

reviews.name: Joe Madison
reviews.body: The phone is high quality with great sound and a brilliant screen. I debated which phone to get, however since I used my old smartphone as a portable computer far more often than I used it to make calls, I decided to go with the 6" screen. People warned me that it was too big to use for calls, but that hasn't been the case for me. AT&T 4G LTE service appears to be ubiquitous where I live, so I've only experienced LTE speeds, which are amazing compared to the 3G phones I updated from. So far I couldn't be happier. The only downside is both Nokia and AT&T pre-load a lot of apps on this phone, so I spent nearly as much time removing unwanted apps as I did downloading favorites.

reviews.name: Econo-mist
reviews.title_review: It was a gamble but one with a great payoff
reviews.body: Ordered this to try it out instead of my iphone 5s and used it for about a week then went back to iphone just to make sure I still liked it and I just couldnt use my iphone wihtout getting frustrated. I love the screen and the features. I am not really a big app user though but the windows store had all my old apps that I used on my iphone with the exception of amplitube. My favoriote feature is the antiglare screen. In noon daylight I have no difficulty viewing the screen not sure how they did that but they did! I have also tried out the note 3 and still prefer this phone. I recommend it over android and iphone I am sure most people will not be dissapointed with the change.

reviews.name: Mehmet Ozyemisci
reviews.title_review: but as I used it I started to love the phone and it's capabilities
reviews.body: Switched to Windows phone after using all the iphone series since they came out. First had mixed feelings due to being very different mentality from Apple, but as I used it I started to love the phone and it's capabilities. More control and access to more features and data management compare to iphone. Apps are quickly catching up with apple's but must admit that still little behind. Using the Microsoft Health Band with the phone gives me an additional comfort that I own this product with Cortana interaction with the Band. I don't plan to go back to Apple unless Apple incorporates memory card or MS falls behind with the coming apps.

reviews.name: Moderator
reviews.title_review: Great flagship phone. Great technology no excuses!
reviews.body: This phone is fantastic. Compare the technology to current 2015 phones and it still holds it's own. The size is something you will get used to after a short while if you are concerned with how big it is. I actually have mine in a case protector and it still fits in normal front pockets. Once you have this phone any try to use other people's phones, you will wonder how you got by with the tiny screens. It is great for watching videos and other media consumption such as Netflix. I have a boom holder on my bed frame which holds this phone and I can watch Netflix all day without having my hands get tired. The battery life is great and the Nokia apps are ahead of their time. The Nokia Mix radio app lets you listen to music ad free and you can even download the music mixes for offline listening so you don't have to worry about using up your data for streaming or spotty connections if you are traveling. Great phone for a great price!

reviews.name: Redhead
reviews.title_review: Nokia Lumia 1520 - Best Phone I have owned in years. Love it and not missing Android (even though I liked Android)
reviews.body: Love this phone. I don't have a single bad thing to say about it. Yes it is large but I knew that going in and it does still fit in my shirt pocket and is light enough to carry up front. Windows Phone 8.1 is much better than Android and I have found all the apps I need at the windows store. After using Samsung Galaxy S series phone for the last 4 years I am very happy to be back on WP. The photos are super. I love the fact that I can take RAW photos and tune them up in Lightroom.

reviews.name: Calee
reviews.title_review: I like my new phone but one huge problem.
reviews.body: I like the phone I updated it to W10 Mobile, but when i tried to use cortana or video recording software, all they got were really silent noise and i can't use the phones mic to talk to people but i can use my headphones mic. I used an online mic test for it and i picked up noise if i got really close to the mic port. I might try to see if i can get my phone repaired. This phone was posted as Refurbished, and it did look refurbished but Refurbish wasn't what happened with the mic. My parents said if its refurbished that means they checked everything to see it work. I can still use my phone but its hard to record life moments without audio and to talk to friends.

reviews.name: Jerry Palmerino
reviews.body: I wanted the latest an greatest Windows Phone device and at the time I purchased this, this was it. Now the darling Windows Phone is the Lumia Icon on Verizon. Hopefully the international version of the Lumia Icon gets released soon. It is the Nokia 930. I will then be able to put that on my AT&T line of service. In the meantime, this is the top of the line Lumia on AT&T. It has better specs than the Lumia 1020 except for the Camera. The 1020 has the awesome 41 megapixel camera, whereas this phone has a still-awesome, 20 megapixel camera. This phone is fast, but not noticeably faster than other Windows Phones. This even includes my AT&T Windows Phone Nokia 520. The only, and I really mean only, issue I have with this phone is its massive 6 inch screen. It still fits in my work pants (khakis in an IT office). The phone is wider and taller than everything else. It is a mini-tablet in every respect. That is not to say that this screen is bad. It is a beautiful screen, perfect for watching movies. The Clear Black technology is great and is easy to read outdoors. I recently upgraded to Windows Phone 8.1 Developer Preview without a hitch. This update makes Windows Phone even better than it already was. This a great phone, if you have big hands, are over 6 feet tall, and/or are looking for a Windows Phone "phablet". PS: I am primarily and Android user, who used to be primarily an iOS user. I have multiple phone lines, which include an iPhone, a HTC One, and this Nokia. I occasionally buy phones such off contract, such as my Nexus 5 and the Nokia 520.

reviews.name: denise santi
reviews.body: The phone was in good condition itself, however the battery would not stay charged more than 2 hrs, had to purchase and get installed a new battery at a cost of $50. The ad said it was refurbished and in working condition, wished I had bought it on eBay, so I could have sent it back and or gotten a rebate for my additional $50.

reviews.name: cooljen
reviews.body: I wanted to come on here and add to the reviews, lol with all the buzz around the iPhone 6 now. I have had my Lumia 1520 since last December and I absolutely love it! I loved it before the recent Windows Phone 8.1 upgrade and now, after that, I love it waaay more! It's almost like a new phone but within the same hardware. Upgraded interface! On to the review - I'm not much of a techie so I'm not going to list a review of every feature. Of course the camera is great and really everything else. I will go through some things I really love about it. Cortana is really awesome. I don't think it is operating yet at full capacity- meaning I don't think I've untapped all of its capabilities yet, but it is really cool. It doesn't talk to me as much as I would like but that's probably because I don't really talk to it - I still feel a little weird talking to my phone! I didn't go through the whole Siri thing, as I never liked the iPhone interface. Back to the phone & Cortana: I love the daily snapshot it gives me - tailored to me from all the things I told it. I love the reminders it gives me - telling me that its time to leave and the traffic, to get to an appointment. Its really helpful. I love the slide down notifications and expanded volume control. I love the new texting style - makes typing a lot of words possible in a really short time! and is so effortless! I love the new update to the already cool live tiles! The transparent background is awesome! I love the new glance screen - the update is just that much cleaner! And of course I've always loved the overall look - both the build of the phone and the interface. I appreciate the interface over a Droid or iPhone interface any day, and furthermore don't get how soooo many people aren't turned on to Window Phone's interface instead! I think Microsoft needs to do better advertising! Maybe stop showing Windows Phones in comparison to Apple. I mean that's great and all - people need to see a comparison but a lot of the earlier ads - that kind of comparison just makes it seem like you're constantly showing Apple as the standard that you're trying to catch up to (standard in popularity of course) but they need to show how Windows Phone stands in its own class! Lastly I really hope they continue to improve the phone. If they continue to make jumps like they did with this WP8 to WP8.1 - they will be lightyears ahead of the competition!!

reviews.name: Zero
reviews.body: I love this phone I've had it since day one. My last one dropped and cracked a few days ago, so I purchased a refurb phone and restored from the back up (one drive) took 20 mins and it's like I never left. I love the Screen size first 6 inch phone, the color is wonderful and visible in direct light. The camera is a must have 20mpx makes this thing glimmer compared to other high end smart phone cameras. Built in NFC and Wireless charging is great (Non At&t model they remove that) (don't recommend the charging case it has no protection and is the reason my last one is dead). The WiFi support AC making this phone fly when connected to a good home network. Windows 10 loads well but heats the phone up and kills battery lift (went back to 8.1 update 3 denim). There are a lot of apps for this phone and using it with Office is great! Hook this phone up to a wireless display using Miracast (no lag) hook in a keyboard Bluetooth and mouse and you have a nice mini PC. I can not say enough good about this phone, wish the corners were not so pointy but other wise great look feel and design. All Windows phone should be like this one.

reviews.name: Zachary and Kayla Pope
reviews.body: Wow! I been a Lumia 925 user for past three years! It was a great phone. In just last month my speaker phone quit so I decided to get something bigger and better! And the 1520 is exactly that! I'm supper satisfied with my purchase from the gizmo trade. Everything works and runs super smooth. I had to cut my sim card to size cause the 1520 takes a Nano sim. And thankfully it worked. Wouldn't recommend everyone to that. I even updated it to windows 10 and it got even better! Shipping was super quick. I ordered on a Friday at 5:00pm and was delivered by the following Monday at 2:00 pm. No bull this phone is humangus!

reviews.name: Greg Harrison
reviews.body: This device took me 2 days of downloading and updating to get to Windows 10 Mobile. Then, after working for another couple of days began to have problems that resulted in lack of internet connectivity through wifi, rendering the whole thing pretty useless for anything except phone calls.

reviews.name: Towbes
reviews.body: Okay, so I bought this phone to replace my iPhone 5. I was an avid iPhone user, but I decided it was time to try something new. This phone out performs my old iPhone in every way! The only down fall is that yes, the app store is somewhat limited, but its okay, because the great increase in screen size allows me to do more on the web! There is a bit of a learning curve, but it is easy to use once you found it out. Now, as a testament as to how durable the phone is! The fourth day I had the phone, I dropped it out of my car and accidentally kicked it into the snow bank. I didn't realize it at the time and the phone spent 13 hours in a pile of snow. It literally was encased in ice, but after thawing it out for about an hour, I was able to resume my angry birds game where I had left off. The ice seems to have had no effect what so ever. Not even a scratch. This phone is a tank! I didn't even have a case on it!!!

reviews.name: Smasher
reviews.title_review: Great phone Microsoft lost it to Android auto
reviews.body: This is a great phone it just too bad Microsoft can't keep up with Android they don't support it anymore and in the end it'll just have to be rooted for Android use Microsoft lost on this one

reviews.name: Tony
reviews.body: This phone is still very well spec'd in 2016. Camera is up there with the best of the best (20MP). Only downside is the larger-than-normal size. The 6" screen is about as big as you'll want a phone. But great for media consumption.

reviews.name: Taylor
reviews.body: Was so excited waiting for this to arrive and when it did, I was quite shocked with how big it was, but I guess I need to pay attention to the size more. But before I even got through the setup, I decided I already loved it. Windows 8 works great and the screen is perfect, everything is bright and clear. The camera is the main reason I got the phone and Im completely happy with it

reviews.name: Zachary
reviews.title_review: ... after non and it came on Monday morning WOW amazing shipping thank you seller best part is product was ...
reviews.body: I bought this phone Saturday after non and it came on Monday morning WOW amazing shipping thank you seller best part is product was in perfect conditions it has a few noticeable scratches on the back but the screen is perfect so happy with my purchase if this phone breaks I hope this is still in stock cause ill be buying another

reviews.name: Drive Right
reviews.body: Great phone. Upgraded to Windows 10 but it did not have individual live tiles for email accounts so I upgraded to Windows 8.1 which is the best phone operating system Microsoft has ever created.

reviews.name: Tech 4x4
reviews.body: So far I am extremely happy with the phone. Now that I have a windows tablet and phone there is no way I would go back to any other operating system. Great screen, phone is fast, amazing camera and incredible battery live. If you are looking for a big screen this is the best option in the market.

reviews.name: Kahlil Gibron Bloedoorn
reviews.body: It is serving its purpose.

reviews.name: A. T. Taylor
reviews.title_review: LOVE IT SO MUCH, I PURCHASED 2 OF THEM!
reviews.body: I fell in love with this phone the moment I picked it up. Still can not believe how thin it is--seems delicately thin. But the screen will blow you a way. Yeah, I thought the size might be too big, well once you use it for a day, you will not want any screen that's smaller especially if you are a baby boomer like me where squinting at that small iPhone screen makes you look silly. This is a screen that you can get some serious consumption done. Windows phone operating system is the best in the market place, modern sleek, information driven--and just down right cool! The apps, can not think of anything I want to do where there isn't a very good app that lets me do it. Fast-wow, is this thing fast, external storage add 64gig with an sd card, sound, loud and full. The camera--wow, nothing on the market beats it except for the lumia 1020. Except for the herd mentality of the American market place, this phone would be on every top seller list! Stop listening to the herd, if you want a great phone, you owe it to yourself to give this a try!

reviews.name: Barry T
reviews.body: Poor Windows Phone... but it's still alive and working surprisingly well (updated to Windows 10). Hey, it's still my daily phone. How many 4-year old phones can you claim that for?

reviews.name: Thunder Cloud
reviews.body: The Nokia Lumia 1520 outclasses other phones with ease. The display is sharp. The pictures are gorgeous. The operating system is exemplary and contains numerous refinements that are simply outstanding. There is a sensing function that detects the amount of ambient light, and it adjusts the color scheme of the display to ensure maximum readability. I am very impressed with this. The call quality is a little muddy when using the speakerphone function. But it isn't bad enough to take a star off. (I'm not convinced the sometimes-muddy quality is caused by the phone exclusively.) I would say that the overall call quality is good, but not pristine. The expandable memory is a plus. I've taken some unwarranted flack about the Lumia 1520's Windows operating system. This is by far the best mobile operating system available. To my personal perspective, Apple's OS is for simple people. Android is very good, but I have had one android device fail inexplicably. But this Windows OS does things that I truly appreciate. I liken my transition from android to windows to driving an old Jeep, and then upgrading to a Mercedes S-500. Simply put, it is just better.

reviews.name: Jennifer Duncan
reviews.title_review: Great time shipped nice just no instruction. But great other wise supper happy
reviews.body: The only bad part is no instructions or key to open the sim and sd part. Everthing top quality though. Arrived on time love this

reviews.name: ALICIA O
reviews.body: Purchased this phone and brought it to AT&T to have it activated, but device was unable to accept or make phone calls. Phone was useless to me.

reviews.name: Casper Pieterse
reviews.body: This is a big phone and will certainly not be for everyone. After watching some reviews online I still did not get the true size until I held it the first time. That said, it is a pretty awesome device. * The screen is truly amazing. It is clear, crisp and responsive and an absolute joy to work on. But at full brightness, it does suck the battery pretty fast. * The Windows Phone 8 OS is coming along nicely and although you will miss some apps (waiting impatiently for FlipBoard) I have found that it addresses all my day to day needs. (see notes below) * Speed is awesome and games like Asphalt 8 runs brilliantly. * The ATT version only has 16GB of Memory for Apps and no wireless charger. (Thanks for that). But not the phones fault. * I added a 32GB micro SD Card for extra media. * The camera is awesome. 20MP is more than enough for most users. * Browsing the web on this device is pretty good. The big screen helps So, Windows Phone 8. The OS got a bad wrap and although there are still some major issues / missing features it is definitely getting better. The user experience is great and fresh when compared to iOS that despite it's makeover, is pretty stale. Things that I miss are: * VPN support (coming) * Notification center (coming) .... not much else The app gap is closing fast and if Microsoft does go in the direction that some media outlets are reporting (dropping royalty fees for Windows Phone [unconfirmed]) we should hopefully see an explosion of devices to challenge android. Since the OS will only get better, I'm happy with my purchase.

reviews.name: JHT
reviews.body: My phone arrived early and is in great condition. There were 2 very small hairline scratches on the screen but it otherwise looks and operates as if it is brand new! Great deal.

reviews.name: Mozzer101
reviews.body: My only grip is window phones don't have a YouTube app. No way to download google chrome. I hate Internet Explorer. Other than those two things the phone is outstanding!

reviews.name: jay
reviews.body: Loved this phone, broke it the second week I had it at work, will get another one, I would recommend this OS to anyone that works a lot with windows

reviews.name: Biftek
reviews.body: I'll buy it three times if I have to. Amazing battery life, perfect screen, awesome camera. I can't find anything bad about it.

reviews.name: ashley helmig
reviews.body: I like this phone I needed a new one bad it does heat up alot from the battery I think but will use it until I can't anymore

reviews.name: TeamHawkins
reviews.title_review: Glad to be able to go back to the phone I love
reviews.body: My favorite phone. Only issue is the volume is pretty low when not used on bluetooth or speaker, otherwise, perfect.

reviews.name: *B*
reviews.body: very good phone, was leary of windows based phone but this phone is great. prob will never go back to anything else. just need more apps for windows.

reviews.name: Stevie H
reviews.body: Didn't work. Wouldn't hold charge. Couldn't read sim card

reviews.name: Amazon Customer
reviews.body: For a Nokia Lumia 1520 I broke when I dropped it. I loved it so much that I got another. There wasn't anything even close to this except the HTC One for Windows and that screen wasn't big enough; not after the Nokia Lumia 1520's 6-in screen. All-in-all, this is a quality phone, great operating system, and the thing was shipped a delivered exactly when I thought it would.

reviews.name: Angel
reviews.body: USED-GADGET: OMG! The phone looks brand new. It has some very minor scratches on the screen (scratches are not even visible because of the smudges and it came with a screen protector) and barely any scratches on the back. The phone came with a charger and a 16GB Micro SD card, which is awesome cause I was planning on buying one. SUPER AWESOME. And the customer support is great!!!! Shipping took only 1 day!

reviews.name: Amazon Customer
reviews.body: Got it second hand from an Amazon Market seller in 2014. In about one year - the SIM reader stopped reading any SIM card (existing or brand new from ATT) . No drops, no water boarding, no opening of the phone. To repair - it meant replacing the entire motherboard - about 1/2 the price of the phone. Was ***great*** while it worked - very good camera, really good screen and surprisingly good battery life (2-3 days on a full charge). Still using it on Wi-Fi only as a tablet - was too big as a day to day phone anyway. Disclaimer: I was a Nokia Lumia fan (900, 950, 1020, 1520) and now moved to Microsoft mid level line (650) - that inherited the hardware and all the good software from Nokia.

reviews.name: E. Dunkle
reviews.body: This is my second windows phone and I really like it. This phone is fast, has great battery life, and is built really well. I would recommend this phone to anyone. The windows phone operating system is smooth and super easy to use and understand. Great phone, great operating system!

reviews.name: Brandon Byrd
reviews.title_review: but overall works great. Everyone likes how big it is
reviews.body: This is my daily use phone. It gets a bit buggy at times, but overall works great. Everyone likes how big it is.

reviews.name: jason g. duncan
reviews.body: Awesome phone, great camera

reviews.name: Yousuf
reviews.title_review: the seller sell a phone that was not working.
reviews.body: the seller is a fraud

reviews.name: TIMOTHY M RICE
reviews.body: so far so good,, this is my first window phones and i like it very much, but i do hope it will last for the two years contract,, 20 months to go,, if it dies on me i will update this post asap

reviews.name: MIke Young
reviews.body: Best phone i ever owned... I like window better Apple.... Android OS sucks..

reviews.name: RTWG
reviews.body: I love this phone! I prefer my Lumia 1520 over my Lumia 950 XL.

reviews.name: Geo lobo
reviews.body: All way I like window phone. And this is the best for me. I wish Microsoft making more.

reviews.name: eric jasman
reviews.body: This is the 2nd time I owned it I love it but the design for the sim an micro sd slot could be better

reviews.name: Janos Nagy
reviews.body: This is a great phone, but the screen is so sensitive that it switches randomly and uncontrollably.

reviews.name: Cathy
reviews.body: Worked just like promised! Love it!

reviews.name: def
reviews.title_review: Bought a second one as this is the best phone I have ever had
reviews.body: Bought a second one as this is the best phone I have ever had. I will keep it going as long as possible or until the new Surface phone comes out, if it comes out.

reviews.name: Katow
reviews.title_review: The original Big Phone. I wear a size 14 ...
reviews.body: The original Big Phone. I wear a size 14 ring. The size of the phone allows me to turn it on its side & increase the space & size of the keyboard. I can text without stepping on other letters.

reviews.name: fwal3606
reviews.body: Great phone

reviews.name: hbomb2008

reviews.name: Steve Taylor
reviews.body: This is my second Nokia 1520. The first one had its issues but this second one infuriates me. The hardware is fantastic. The phone is fast, the screen is very large and looks great, the camera takes good pictures and video, the processor is fast, etc. However the software is terrible. The interface is great, much better then IOS and Android but it ends there. This phone has more problems then I can possibly list but I'm going to mention just a few. * Phone locks up on a daily basis for no reason. * Camera locks up almost every time it's used. * Locks up when switching from still camera to video. * Intermittent keyboard shows up when it feels like it. Phone must be rebooted. * Bluetooth is on but when call comes in it disconnects. * Must be rebooted when entering a new wifi area (such as between home and work). * Copy and paste only works sometimes. * Deletes contacts randomly. * Deletes apps randomly. * Randomly turns itself off. * Music app randomly deletes downloaded music. * Settings change on their own. * Rebooting takes up to five minutes. * Email system has many flaws. * No YouTube app and all aftermarket ones stink. * Low amount of apps available but not a huge issue. * Alarm is not usable unless you keep your ringer on. What company would do that? There's really too many problems to list here. This phone is running WM10 and gets all of the updates. I keep a minimum amount of apps loaded to simplify problems. Cache cleaner and performance apps are run weekly. Reloading WM10 hasn't helped. Windows has a great opportunity to be the leader in cell phone operating systems but they just can't seem to get their act together. Too bad. Skip it. NOTE: Do not buy a phone from BREED. They sold me a new phone that was clearly used. Amazon was going to make good on it and take it back but I was in the middle of moving to a different state and couldn't return it.

reviews.body: It's a great device, simple to use and easy switch from iPhone. Screen is huge, easy to read and see. Little too big for a smaller hand, some times requires two hands to operate, so for work on a go while driving use voice feature to text and email. Not many apps just yet, but has everything I used on iPhone, so not a big deal. You will look goofy if you put this tablet to your ear, it's just that big and bulky. You will notice how fast this processor is, I do not wait for any app to open, almost instantaneous. If you like to take pictures, this thing has 20mgpixl cam, not as good as my wife's Lumia 1020, but much better then my iPhone. reviews.name: Cellphone Junkie
reviews.title_review: Breath Of Fresh Air From Android And IOS
reviews.body: I am a self admitted cell phone addict. i have various versions of iPhones up to IOS 7and Android phones up to Kit Kat. I became board with the same old stuff so I decided with some caution that I would make the switch to Windows Phone 8. I was very fearful of a lack of apps, but it turns out that the majority of the apps that I used on other platforms were available on WP8. The ones that weren't available had similar apps that were as good as or better than the original. The phone itself is a work of art. The build quality is every bit as good if not better than any model of iPhone. The screen is second to none in my opinion. Its bright, and the colors are incredible. Its very easy to read in sunlight. The button locations are very intuitive. The speaker is very loud and also clear. The battery life is amazing. I consider my self an average to slightly above average cell phone user. The phone comes off the charger at 4:15am every day. Buy the time I go to bed at 10:00pm I still have any where from 65 to 70 percent charge left. The phone is large. There is no question about that, but its also thin and feels very good in the hand. If you are looking for a large screen phone that does just about everything perfect, then look no further. The toughest choice you will have to make is which color to get.

reviews.name: Kevin Zhang
reviews.title_review: Live tile is awesome, camera is awesome, system is FAST
reviews.body: I used to own a Galaxy Note I since its release, was happy with its size and the abundant apps but for the past 6 month I started to feel the pain for Android's lousy and slow software. The LTE can also suck all the power from a fresh charge in 6~8 hours, so I had to turn off ATT data network anywhere I can use WIFI. Last Friday I finally jumped to Lumia 1520. Now it has been 3 days and I can't express how happy I am! Here are few things I feel great about this phone: 1. The system is fast and smooth - hardly feel delay when switch apps. 2. Integration with Office makes open email attachment so convenient and productive 3. Photos took by the camera are crispy clear and I have not tried to adjust the settings yet. 4. Live tile, man, I love live tile. With a 6 inch screen and adjustable tile size, all my calendar appointments, the weather, the battery usage, the news app I installed, all dynamically displays like music. A quick glance and I know what is going on and what I will up to, no app launch is needed! 5. The voice enabled Nokia GPS drive is accurate, clear and LOUD, it will retire all your GPS device forever. 6. If you use Skydrive, the integration with Skydrive is really smooth and seamless. 7. Battery performance is exceeding my expectation. With LTE or WIFI (I even don't know which I am using now), after a relatively heavy 2~3 hour web usage and a full day random use, I can still have 50% power left by the end of the day. Now are few things I don't feel great about: 1. I really want to have the App/function to automatically mute my phone in working/sleeping hours but seems it is not supported on Windows phone 2. The phone is big as we know, so one hand dial is virtually impossible. If you are driving, even pick up the call will be a problem with one hand(I know, I know, don't drive and .....) 3. I still wish I can have those missed Apps I had on Android, comparing those app I installed on Galaxy Note (about 20 of them), I found all my apps in Windows Phone App store except 3 are not available. btw, anyone want to jump to windows phone, you can check here for available windows phone apps: [...] then you can decide if some critical Apps are missing when you switch the ship.

reviews.name: shorty
reviews.body: Craptastic phone!

reviews.name: Gaurav Singhal
reviews.body: Lumia 1520 is one of the best phones I have ever used. Following are the few things I believe are the best in this phone compared to other phones ( I have some links towards the end to back my review ) * This phone has one of the best battery life, it has a huge 3400 mAh battery, and i generally have 50-60% left at the end of day (1) * This phone has one of the best screens. Full HD 1080p and the best outdoor visibility (2) * The second best camera in any phone right now, best being lumia 1020. 20MP camera which takes great photos in low light and OIS makes photos/videos crisp. OIS (optical Image stabilization) means the lens uses mechanical ball bearing and magnetically powered motors for stabilization during photo as well as video. Or put more simply the lens moves in the opposite direction to compensate for any small hand movements/vibrations to make the photo/video more stable. * To my knowledge, only two smartphones right now can shoot photos in RAW/DNG ( Lumia 1020 and Lumia 1520 ) (3) * One of the loudest and best speakers on any phone. No need to buy the small $100 portable bluetooth speakers, because the speakers on this phone are loud enough. * The best innovation in this phone is audio recording. Phone has 4 HAAC microphones, and allows directional audio capture for the best noise free recordings of events (4) * Nokia owns the Here Maps(Navteq) so you can download offline maps for anywhere in the world for free. Thats right, you have a worldwide GPS with the up-to-date maps. No need to use crazy amount of cellular data while using google maps or worrying about losing navigation when there is no data connection far from cities * I use my smartphone to check time, but hate clicking the power button every time. Lumia 1520 comes with Glance screen which is always on, shows time and notifications without touching the device. Uses only 4-5% extra battery a day. * Another Lumia exclusive feature is double tap to wake, comes in very handy while phone is sitting on your desk. * In cold weather ability to use your phone with any gloves, also comes in very handy versus buying special gloves for most other phones. This is a large phone, so be mindful of the size before u order. It fits comfortably in my pocket(even jeans), and my hand ( I dont have giant hands). I picked my wife's iphone 4 recently and it felt like a flip phone. Its amazing how quickly we adapt, whats normal to us changes quick. I am of the opinion a large display phone (phtablet) is better than owning two separate devices (phone and tablet). Almost everyone who sees my phone makes a comment, but i have noticed that only iphone users are generally almost hostile about the size of Lumia 1520. iphone users think owning an iphone is cool, but in reality something that 50% of the population owns cannot be cool by definition. I am not saying owning a Nokia makes you cool automatically but an iphone is def not cool anymore. Also, many of these iphone users might run to buy a bigger phone when apple makes one (5) Android is a great option too but I wouldn't buy an android phone because of the malware issue (6) and in general of google poilcies, in Eric Schmidt's own words (7) So to wrap up i think this is one of the best smartphones hardware wise and Windows Phone is a great OS, so if you are in the market for a new phone give this a try, go to your local At&T store play with it and more competition means us the consumer wins. Links from above: (1) blog.gsmarena.com/nokia-lumia-1520-battery-life-test/ (2) conversations.nokia.com/2013/10/28/lumia-1520-big-screen-clever-technology/ (3) conversations.nokia.com/2013/10/29/another-nokia-first-digital-negatives-raw-dng-lumia/ (4) mynokiablog.com/2013/11/12/the-concept-of-nokias-directional-recording-explained-lumia-1520-and-quad-microphones/ (5) youtube.com/watch?v=oprUI6nupfc (6) news.yahoo.com/99-mobile-malware-targeted-android-devices-last-164439954.html (7) youtube.com/watch?v=o-rvER6YTss

reviews.name: Sky Lodge Properties, Inc.
reviews.title_review: Do not upgrade to windows 10, it will mess it up totally!
reviews.body: I have four of these phones. The first one I bought new, but dropped the poor thing and the screen gradually went black and unusable. So I bought three used ones from different sellers. Tip: Do not upgrade to windows 10, it will totally mess it up. I upgraded two of them, I am glad I still have one left with windows 8.1. One of the used ones barely works if not plugged in, so I bought a little solar charger which can be charged with a wall outlet as well and it is happy. I use one as a phone and it works circles around any other brand of phone when it comes to conference calls. The battery on that one never quits, it is totally amazing. They take excellent printable pictures and edit pictures to look their best. Windows 10 lost all my contacts three times (!) but because I have so many of them, the app "Transfer my Data" restored them from one of my other phones. Windows 10 will not show thumbprints on the pinned website, which makes that feature useless to me. One of my phones I overloaded with pictures and it quit. So I let it rest in a drawer and then deleted all these (hundreds) of pictures. Now it works fine. I think I can resurrect the phone that doesn't want to work unless it is plugged in by deleting the pinned explorer pages. Might as well since it doesn't show thumb prints. I had upgraded to windows 10 with it hoping it will help the battery life, but it didn't.

reviews.name: Chris M.
reviews.body: My 5s was smashed to oblivious (in a liferpoof case too.. weird?). So I figured it was time for something new. I was very hesitant, nervous, and first question I asked ATT was (when can I return it?). It was huge, bold, loud, and shiny, and seemed cool on the surface. I went over my head, being a cloud advocate, everything I would have to do (contacts.. iCloud calendars, pictures, tasks, email accounts..) Before this, it was seamless, get a new iPhone, plug in my icloud account, and boom... done.. But sometimes seamless is boring.. Here's the things for you iPhone advocates you will have to do without.. lets get that out there now. (I have a iMac, MacBook, two ipads, wife has iPhone, AppleTV etc... all connected under one account) - iCalendar is gone on this phone. You can access a very mundane version of it through the phones IE browser, but it's impossible to read, zoom out, navigate, or add / edit events - iCloud storage is gone. There is no storage access with Apple's iCloud, completely different system - The beloved iMessage is gone. If you have friends on the iMessage system, they better get used to the old "green" text and using cellular to get in contact with you. No way around that unless you use apps like facebook, whatsapp etc... - Photostream is gone - And a bunch of obvious things because it's Windows, not Apple Now here is why I LIKE this phone - The screen is gorgeous. Hands down, best screen on the market, 6" full 1080p deliciousness - 20MP Cam with 1080p. The picture quality is ridiculous. And paired with the Nokia Creative app, you can bust out some almost pro-like DSLR type photos with high quality video - The phone itself. For being such a monstrosity of a phone, it feels great to hold. Landscape view is awesome, and it actually fits my pocket just fine (I'm a dude who wears pants, no murse) - The live-tiles, OS, and navigation is top-bar quality. The phone is just fun to navigate through, and with high quality apps. (Weave, MixMusic, News etc...) The ability to rearrange to your liking from size, colors, live tyles, backgrounds etc is awesome. The updates on the tiles are a plus, one thing you don't have with iPhone (widgets for Android comes to mind). Easily spot weather updates, any news.. updates to facebook etc.. - CPU. This thing is fast.. opening apps, switching between apps, it just so responsive and barely has a hiccup - Games / Video etc... Gaming is great on this thing. If you're an XBOX ONE user, using this as a second screen is pretty sweet. The games for the phone itself are pretty quality, look great, and the extra space with the screen size is a plus. Watching videos on this thing is on par with your quality tablets out there In conclusion.... Though this is a step away from what I'm used to with Apple, it's been a welcome change. I've tried Android and could not get into, and did not like it all. This however, being windows based, has been pretty awesome. And so far I'm satisfied. If you are a iPhone user, I don't think the transition will be bad unless you were a heavy cloud user, you'll have to switch from everything Apple based, to Windows cloud based (onedrive, sky drive.. etc...). All in all superb phone, definitely will hang onto this one for a year, until the next thing lol..

reviews.name: Andrew D. Lossing
reviews.body: ... but I don't mind it. Yep, it's the biggest Windows Phone out there and a rival for the Android "phablets" out there, but this one has better internals than any of them, on top of a much more user-friendly user experience. That's right, WP8 has been around long enough for me to say it without fear of immediately being burnt at the stake: Windows Phone is a faster, better mobile OS than Android. Power users will sometimes complain about the lack of one or two apps upon which they rely on the other system, and while that's legitimate in some cases, I've found WP to do everything I need a phone to for years now. I am an Android user as well, and my Nexus 7 sees plenty of use, but I wouldn't want Google's OS as my go-to device for communication. WP8's core features are so bullet-proof and fast to use that I am sure I will be sticking with them for my phone for a long time, even though I'm invested in Android's ecosystem on my tablet. The best thing to happen for WP has definitely been Nokia's risky business move to exclusively focus on this OS. Their hardware is simply beautiful, as well as reliable (I've used the 900 and 920 for quite awhile) and top-notch. When you hold them and use them, their devices have every bit as much appeal as do Apple's, but they don't even come close to overlapping. Nokia's design is focused on color, freshness, sleekness and practicality. I remember talk when the first Lumia, the 800, came out of how the phone hardware mimicked the OS's bright and bold but utilitarian design, and they've kept that mentality going. Last year's flagship was the 920, then the 1020 with its beastly camera stepped in with upgraded specs, and the slimmer 925 also made an appearance, but as an overall poster child of what OS and hardware can do together, the real king is the 1520. You can read over the specs for yourself: 1080p IPS display, Snapdragon 800 quad-core 2.2GHz processor, 20MP optically-stabilized camera. Those sound great. But even great specs don't mean everything, the key thing is if they work. They work! The 1520 is a massive phone, but it is all polish, with no real faults to find. The whole phone runs at blazing speed with the top-end processor. Size is the major factor in whether this phone appeals to you. Photos don't really do it justice - you have to see it in the polycarbonate to grasp how large it really is. That said, it uses its size in the best way possible: the beautiful screen. I love IPS technology; its color reproduction is excellent, not only saturated and vivid but accurate, and such things matter on a 6" screen. The back of the phone is Nokia-standard toughpolycarbonate, either matte or glossy (in the case of the colorful versions - I've only seen the red, so I can't be totally sure on the others). I prefer the higher-quality feel of the matte on any Nokia device, but with this one it's especially important, because you need grip to hang onto such a large device. To be sure, its weight is quite reasonable, just heavy enough to feel solid and reliable, but there are lots of times I don't have my fingers locked around its edges, but am letting it lie in my palm while I use it. The matte finish of the black phone sticks just enough to the surface of my palm to be comfortable doing so. The 1520 is also nicely thin. In fact, I think its dimensions and weight are close to perfect. They scream good design. The OS update that allows three rows of live tiles comes in especially handy, since you can get almost everything you need onto the screen without scrolling, and even with large tiles, which report a lot of information on what is going on with the app, making this an even better glance-worthy device than the other WP models. Lastly, the camera is on par with other Nokia models (not including the 1020, which is a class unto itself) in performance, with a couple of caveats. One, the maximum aperture is somewhat smaller (f/2.4 instead of f/2.2 on the 920), meaning that this camera has to bump ISO sooner than the 920 in low light. You can still set ISO manually, which I recommend. ISO 100 shots look buttery-smooth. This is also the first camera on a Nokia device to support RAW (DNG) files, which I have yet to test in Lightroom but am looking forward to getting my hands on. All in all, this phone is impressive enough to warm a person who thinks "phablets" are dumb, which incidentally was me. I'm more than willing to make the size trade-off for the many excellent features the 1520 boasts, and am looking forward to what Nokia and Microsoft have in store for their new flagship device!

reviews.name: Super Heavy
reviews.title_review: The best phone I've ever owned.
reviews.body: This morning I dropped my phone without realizing it while walking through the lawn in the rain. It sat out in the rain for about ten minutes before I realized what happened and went looking for it. It still works, which prompted me to write this review. This is the third Windows Phone that I have owned and, without question, the best phone I have ever owned. My wife has a Galaxy Note 3, which I liked so much that I nearly got one for myself, but, after seeing her experience with it after owning it for nearly a year, I'm glad I didn't. My battery lasts triple the time of most phones that I see and I can easily get through 24 hours with only about 30 minutes to an hour on the charger. It's such a pleasure to use on a daily basis; the newest features (Cortana, voice text, swipe keyboard, etc) are incredible and I use them daily. Everything tends to "just work", which is a great thing for a phone. I need functionality from my computer, but I need speed and ease-of-use from my phone and that's one are in which the Windows Phone platform beats out most Android phones. It's built like a tank; I have dropped it multiple times and there is barely a scratch. I will admit, there are times when it's size can be awkward, but I feel that all the times when it's so nice to have a big screen (watching movies, reading, playing games, showing pictures) outweigh any inconvenience. Some recommendations:don't buy the 32GB model. You can buy a 64GB microSD card (under 40 on Amazon) for less than the difference in cost and end up with more space than you will ever use. I'm also on the developer's preview build of the Windows Phone OS; I wouldn't recommend that to most people as the current release has all of the features you want with less bugs. It's nice to get a lot of features ahead of release but they tend to be buggy.

reviews.name: Santosh G
reviews.body: Let me start by saying this phone is amazing.This is my 6th windows phone in a span of 1 year. I keep phone maximum for 3 months and sell it with good value. Earlier i had Lumia 1020 which is amazing phone too. I was in market for a mini ipad.Then i came across this phone . So i thought why not buy Lumia 1520 which can be used as a mini tablet and phone.I have no regrets in buying this phone. Below is my experience with this phone. Form Factor: Yes phone is little big. As this is a phablet category, the size is expected.We cant have a SUV's room in a compact car. So the benefits of large screen is obvious. Also at the same time there will be some inconvinience. Both Hands: Yes most times you need to use both hands. For instance, you cant use back button without using 2nd hand. But i got used to it.After couple weeks ownership , i dont feel this as a inconvinience any more. It matters most in a CAR where you need to handle the phone single handed. So all the time i mount my phone and i can use single hand. Screen: Screen is great and retina. But if you use phone screen without any protector then the screen is very slippery. Camera: Didnt test much but looks as good as lumia 1020 with less zoom. Slim. This phone is very slim when compared to lumia 1020. there is no bulge on the back so it sits flat.I se phone for movies at gym. Lumia 1020's camera bulge was always a chalange at gym. As 1520 sits flat, it is more secure. Speed: I dont think i see much speed improvement over 1020. Though it is quad core ,system still takes time to repsond on certain apps.I believe the speed has to do with particular apps then the phones hardware.When i switched to 1520 ,i thought some lagging in 1020 will be gone in 1520/. but certains apps still lagg. Lanyard: I miss Lanyard of lumia 1020 in this phablet. As this is a big phone, Nokia must have Lanyard option. To remedy this, i added my own . I used incipio air case and added Lanyard to the speaker grill. It works great as the case is strong. Speakers:It is almost same as lumia 1020 speaker with 10-15% improvement in volume. The clarity is same. Both speakers are great. Ear piece could be louder. I dont know but Nokia Lumia series suffers with low ear piece volume. Red Lumia. Red is slippery as every one suggested. Incipio case took care of it. Tiles: Extra column for tiles is a plus. Now one can see more information without moving the screen. Side Keys: Side keys are too flat. It is quite difficult to find volume keys and lock keys .It could be better like lumia 1020. Phone in public: Yes it is eye catching. It doesnt look good if you talk on this phablet in public. But who cares.when Iphone first came, it looked too BIG. but it has become new NORM now. So people will get used to it as phablets become more popular.Also it keep you out of crowd. Pocket: It easily slides into pocket. In my formals and jeans i have no issue in sliding the phone. It fits and doesnt pop out of pocket. As it is slim, the extra length doesnt bother me. Wireless charging. I am really mad on ATT on removing wireless charging from this phone. Hell with the technology and standards. IF they care too much then why did they sell qi wireless chargers. Now that every one got one qi wireless chargers they removed this from phone.ATT ------ in this regard. battery: Awesome. It has very good battery life.It is almost twice that of lumia 1020. I tested battery by turning on everything.Even though the location was turned on, the battery drain was not significant. I believe if location is not used by any app then system turns it off.

reviews.name: Trenton Bennett
reviews.body: The short summary: I've been a long-time user of Android phones but a few months ago I decided to try the move to a Windows Phone. I thought I'd miss some of the goodies, but the truth is, Windows Phone has been great. I bought this through AT&T Next--I don't want to bore you with AT&T details, but I'll put some of that info at the end for anybody who wants to know. The Lumia 1520 is great hardware, but will take some getting used to because of its size. Being bigger than a Phablet but only slightly more portable than a tablet, this slab-like body I have dubbed "The Slablet". The full review: About the phone The Nokia Lumia 1520 is very thin for its width and height. It barely fits in a pocket, but it doesn't take up much space once it's there. The screen is huge, nearly filling the front, and the slight raised bump on the back for the camera lens isn't very noticeable. The black body feels tactile and not slick, with a matte finish, but I went one extra step and skinned it with the Skinomi TechSkin that makes it look like woodgrain. It takes big hands to be able to wrangle this phone: it's skinny, but it's a big slab just the same. If you can get used to this, then the size pays off in the quality of the screen. The OLED screen is very bright and it auto-dims very well in various conditions. No screen seems to do well in direct sunlight, but I have to credit Nokia because this one comes very close. The battery charges fairly quickly, but the battery usage is amazingly good: I tend to top off the charge every 2 or 3 days instead of having to worry whether I have to charge up every night. Side note: while we're on the subject, the Lumia charging pad does NOT work. The manual says it is supported, but as you will see in reviews of the charging pad, it doesn't work on the 1520: the power induction technology was changed and isn't compatible. The phone powers up and down very quickly, apps respond fast on launch, and the sound quality is very good in standard phone calls, so-so in speakerphone, and excellent in Bluetooth. There aren't anywhere near as many apps in the Windows Phone Store as there are in Google's Play Store or Apple's store, but I've found plenty to do whatever I wanted (including ports of popular games like Angry Birds). There is a KitKat Launcher app that will run the Droid OS on Windows, and it runs pretty well...but I haven't found that to be a "port my old apps" solution because it doesn't have the ability to run the Play Store and pull down my apps--some side-loading required. Eventually I realized I just didn't need some of the things I used before because Windows Phone has an equivalent. The camera takes wonderful high-resolution 20MP images. Using it is easy: even with the phone locked, you can turn it sideways in your hands, hold it like a traditional point-and-shoot camera, and use the button on the 'top' right to snap pictures, adjusting your shooting (or video) settings with the touchscreen. The flash works very well, and it's rare that I move around enough to cause motion blur. Pinch-to-zoom works, but more importantly the Nokia Camera app (recently rebranded "Lumia Camera") will let you adjust the most minute "manual mode" settings that any camera pro would love to play with, such as ISO, flash settings, etc. There's also a built-in image editor that I've used to tweak color balances, crop, and otherwise adjust images to save me the trouble of loading them into an image editing program on a computer. About the Windows Phone OS If you've used Windows 8 or an Xbox One or a Surface tablet, you've already been exposed to how the OS behaves. Every app has a square tile that represents it, and the tiles are large and easy to tap on. The main screen lets you put whatever tiles on it you like, and they scroll from top to bottom--but if you need one that's not on the main screen, a quick swipe to the right will pull up the list of everything on the phone. The Phone OS runs very smooth, launching apps quickly and multi-tasking well: I can run music via Bluetooth while navigating on the maps and when a phone call comes in, it all gets handled easily--and most importantly, consistently. The interface will pretty much look and feel the same for most of the apps that you use: you have some buttons for interaction, you have an ellipsis button "[...]" that brings up options, and the menus are large, bright text on a black background. Swiping and flipping around in the settings is fast and easy. I like the fact that the dialing menu makes it easy to flip through call history, contacts, speed dial, and voicemail, and that voicemail messages are pulled down to the phone and can be played like any media player app, with play/pause buttons. The only app that misbehaves is Facebook, and that seems to be the rule these days on more than one device I used it on. Facebook's interface is inconsistent and its behavior sometimes gets weird. I haven't had a single app crash on the phone, but Facebook comes close. So let's talk a moment about the details: Cortana. This voice-driven virtual assistant was a brilliant idea. After interviewing personal assistants for executives, celebrities, and more, the product team came up with a personality that is intended to handle your every need through voice interaction. This is a great app, but unfortunately only when it works. For example, I said, "Cortana, set up an recurring appointment on my calendar, for every Monday and Wednesday, starting on January first. Name the appointment "Yoga"." Believe it or not, this worked. But then I try something I read on a website about Cortana, and instead of it providing me an interactive response, Cortana brings up a Bing search on my screen and leaves me to figure it out. And yet...I was running the other day and she popped into my Bluetooth to tell me I just got a text message. We talked our way through playing it back to me, repeating it, and then calling the person back, all without touching a button. So when it works, it works well...and when it doesn't, you just wish it were consistent. OneDrive: this used to be called SkyDrive, and it's Microsoft's built-in online storage. I use OneDrive all the time with no real fuss. I can count on it to automatically upload my photos and videos, I can open documents I have stored out there, and it's actually more hassle-free on the phone than it can be on a PC. I don't currently run Office on my phone because I have a Surface Pro, but it does appear that the integration with Windows Phone for Office is probably better than the weird and limited versions of such apps on Android. Mail: Outlook looks and feels like the browser-based version, but seems to behave a little better. I've also added my Gmail accounts and the UI looks and behaves the same, but they appear as separate icons on the main screen. Maps and Driving: this is probably the only sticking point with a Windows Phone: Microsoft's identity crisis with Nokia. The Maps app works very well and is easy to work with. It gives driving directions by voice or lets you just view step-by step text instructions. There are two Nokia apps on the phone (Here Drive+ and My Commute) that are fantastic...but limited. So for example, the tile for My Commute regularly shows me how long it's going to take me to drive home, and gives a red exclamation point if there are any reported accidents along the way. Microsoft's Bing Maps updates traffic about every 2 minutes. When I'm driving, if I go a different route, both apps make a note of it, and amazingly enough, I get tiles at the top of the screen showing me the approximate times for each route, so I can know which one has the worst traffic. All of this works because there's a handoff under the covers between My Commute, Here Drive+ and Bing Maps. But sometimes when I launch My Commute, it doesn't make the handoff and it never gets started tracking the commute. Other times, it's supposed to present me with the Start button and it doesn't come up--the main screen just gives me options to add more commutes or delete one. The same happens with Here Drive+, sometimes I ask it to give me directions and it doesn't launch Bing Maps. Or it doesn't give me voice. Another app that when it works, is amazing, and when it doesn't, you just wish it were consistent. In the end, the Nokia Lumia 1520 is a really good overall data device: it is almost as capable as a full-blown tablet and it's also a great piece of hardware for a phone. The features of the Windows Phone OS range from amazing to mediocre, but overall it can do just about any basic day-to-day task that you might expect a smartphone to do. Microsoft have done a good job of marrying the OS to the device, with a few awkward Nokia-app fumbles here and there. Overall if you're looking for a Windows Phone, this is the best model that has the ability to add storage. You should probably try to get your hands on one first though to see if this is really something for your hands that you will be willing to haul around. AT&T Next info: to be honest, I spent more time agonizing over whether to take the plunge with their plan than I did over whether to switch to Windows Phone. After research, phone calls to AT&T Customer Service, and some support Chat sessions, I finally figured it out. The newest smartphones always cost hundreds of dollars, and the days where a phone company was willing to eat those costs to get your business are coming to an end. AT&T gives you a bit of upgrade leeway with Next because even though you're effectively agreeing to buy the phone at full price and stretch out the payments, there's also a certain window towards the end of that time where you can walk away from the payments and trade up...so long as, like in the past, you're entering into a new agreement.
